Graphical abstract Residential consumers can get the opportunity to render their energy usage responsive to time-varying prices by participating in demand response (DR) programs through home energy management systems (HEMSs). The consumer’s primary motivation behind utilizing a HEMS is to reduce cost, which entails a shifted or reduced power consumption associated with the impairment in daily comfort. In this regard, a HEMS needs to maintain the consumer’s comfort while minimizing his/her cost. Besides, a residential consumer may desire to use various appliances in a day. The managed operation of these appliances in a HEMS environment results in diverse types of discomfort peculiar to each appliance. Therefore, this study initially develops discomfort models in a comprehensive manner and then proposes a new multi-objective HEMS, aiming to bring cost savings to the consumer without considerable discomfort in his/her daily life under various operating conditions such as different pricing tariffs and stochastic scenarios. The results prove that the proposed HEMS conveniently achieves the optimal energy usage pattern of the household depending on consumer preferences and priorities. Moreover, it is revealed that a residential consumer can make an explicit cost-comfort analysis and appreciate a meaningful balance between his/her cost-saving and comfortable lifestyle. i t Function to suppress the deviation Ψ i Delay ratio 1 Introduction 1.1 Background and motivation The world has been experiencing an ongoing transformation process into an energy-dependent era. This necessarily makes energy an essential need for individuals or countries, leading to the growth of energy requirement [1]. Some of the latest released reports [2–5] give statistical information over this growth on a global scale. For example, according to the 2020 energy outlook, the average increase in energy demand is expected to be 0.7% per year within the next three decades, which was 2.0% per year in the past two decades [5]. The expected slowdown in the rate of demand increase is assumed to be the reflection of the persistent impact of the Covid-19 pandemic on global economic activity and power market. However, the primary energy demand is projected to rise by 25% up to 2050 as the restrictions are eased over the next few years [5]. Similar to the increasing trend in primary energy demand, the need for electrical energy, as the most widely used form of energy, is reported to expand by 80% until 2050 across the world with an annual increment of around 2% [5]. Among the end-user sectors in the power market, residential buildings hold a considerable share i . e . , about 40 % in total electricity usage worldwide [4]. Furthermore, the electrical energy consumption of residential buildings is projected to double within thirty years [4], indicating that their contribution to the growth of electrical energy demand will increase. Thus, the efforts that seek to integrate residential buildings into demand response (DR) programs on the purpose of peak demand reduction and system load curve modification become even more important. DR programs aim to reshape the load profile of consumers according to a utility signal, which may be an incentive (i.e., incentive-based DR programs (IBDRPs)) or a time-varying electricity pricing tariff (i.e., price-based DR programs (PBDRPs)). IBDRPs are implemented on the basis of an award-penalty mechanism and allow utilities to get direct access to consumer dwellings for the remote control of appliances. However, this may demotivate consumers to join DR programs due to privacy concerns and involuntary loss of comfort. Differently from IBDRPs, consumers have self-control on their appliances in PBDRPs by being responsive to various electricity pricing tariffs implemented by the Distribution System Operator DSO , such as Time of Use TOU pricing, Real Time/Day Ahead Pricing RTP / DAP or Critical Peak Pricing CPP [6]. As an emerging and prevailing technology, the home energy management system HEMS is deemed an effective tool for enabling the participation of residential consumers in DR programs. A HEMS can be defined as an intermediary system that provides the means of visualization, monitoring, management, and automation of the energy use by appliances or the entire household [7]. Typically, a system needs inputs to produce outputs, and the HEMS is not an exception. There may exist a variety of inputs to a HEMS like consumer preferences e . g . , timing and power usage of an appliance , electricity pricing tariff, and forecasted outside temperature. Processing all these inputs, a HEMS provides outputs such as less use of energy, lower bill of electricity, and peak shaving. However, the relevant outputs of a HEMS can be achieved through shifting or reducing the energy consumption of household appliances, which inevitably causes some types of discomfort depending on the operational features of appliances. Although lowering the electricity bill is the primary goal of a consumer, the effect of discomfort also needs to be relieved in order to promote the willingness of consumers for DR programs. These are two conflicting objectives of HEMSs. Thus, the energy management problem in a HEMS necessitates a modelling strategy based on a multi-objective optimization framework from the end-user perspective. To that end, this paper attempts to find optimal consumption patterns of household appliances such that the trade-off between the daily electricity bill and discomfort is conveniently achieved under various scenarios and electricity pricing tariffs. 1.2 Literature review Optimizing the energy usage of a household by a HEMS has been a great interest subject for researchers. Hence, there exist many research papers on HEMSs in the literature. A HEMS manages the multitude of household appliances. Thus, the appropriate DR models of these appliances need to be obtained so as to establish a functional HEMS structure. In this regard, researchers have used the approach of analysing household appliances with similar operational attributes under general DR classes to ease the modelling complexity as in references [8–60], where there is no convergence regarding how to entitle DR classes. Similar to the previous studies, this study also introduces DR models of household appliances. However, to develop a more comprehensive HEMS structure, a detailed categorization of household appliances considered in the literature is presented in this paper. The detailed mathematical models and explanations of these appliance categories are provided in the next section. Through the presented way of categorization, all types of appliances that a consumer may own in his/her household are involved in the HEMS. Furthermore, it enables to develop discomfort models associated with each appliance category. The studies within the HEMS literature essentially pursue the common goal of designing an optimal energy consumption scheme for residential consumers. However, researchers address the optimization problem with various objectives to meet this scheme. Since paying less for electricity usage is one of the major concerns of residential consumers, a considerable number of studies in the literature are focused on cost minimization [10–37]. For example, in [14], the authors have proposed a gradient-based PSO algorithm to minimize the electricity cost of a household with interruptible, deferrable, and thermal appliances. The researchers in [22] have presented an energy management model for a home including own-generation and storage facilities to minimize the energy usage cost of electrically controllable, optically controllable, and thermostatically controllable appliances. A residential household load management model has been studied by the researchers in [36] to minimize the total electricity cost based on a price-based electricity tariff along with renewable energy utilization. Even though HEMSs have been proven to produce financial benefits for the consumer budget, as stated in the aforementioned studies, they ineluctably require consumers to compromise on their daily routine of electricity usage to a certain extent. This compromise is inherently related to loss or impairment of energy comfort, which can be defined as discomfort in a word. Each appliance in a household is responsible for fulfilling particular tasks depending on its operational feature. Thus, the management of each appliance by the HEMS results in a specific type of discomfort. Some researchers have considered discomfort handling in addition to cost minimization from a multi-objective optimization perspective. Three types of discomfort have been discussed in the literature. The first one is delay or waiting time due to the shifting of time flexible appliances. The second one is temperature deviation due to the thermostat setting of temperature-based appliances, and the third one is power deviation due to reducing the power of instant power-based appliances. The researchers in [38–47] have aimed at minimizing cost and delay, while cost and temperature deviation minimization have been studied by the researchers in [48–52]. Unlike the previous studies, the researchers in [53–58] have integrated the simultaneous minimization of cost, delay, and temperature deviation into their problems, while cost, delay, and power deviation minimization have been considered in [59,60]. For example, in [41], researchers have implemented a multi-objective evolutionary algorithm for cost reduction and waiting time minimization. In [56], a pricing-based HEMS has been proposed to minimize the temperature deviation for thermostatically controlled appliances and the delay for interruptible and non-interruptible appliances jointly with cost minimization. In [60], the relationship between cost efficiency and consumer preferences has been investigated through a multi-objective optimization problem aiming to minimize cost, delay, and power deviation in a smart house with power and time controllable appliances. 1.3 Contribution Based on the detailed survey of the HEMS literature, our ultimate conclusion is threefold. Firstly, most of the mentioned studies stay focused on cost minimization. Secondly, a few studies address the discomfort resulting from the HEMS’s operation. Thirdly, the discomfort types considered in these studies are limited and thus fail to evaluate the joint effect of all possible discomfort types, such as interruption of preemptive appliances, delay of non-preemptive appliances, power deviation of instant power-based appliances, energy insufficiency of energy based-appliances, and temperature deviation of temperature-based appliances. The mathematical models of all these discomfort types are developed in this study and presented in the next section. Despite the valuable contributions of the referred studies to the existing literature on HEMS implementations, to the best of the authors’ knowledge, there is not yet a study that discusses the effect of appliance category-based discomfort types on HEMS outputs from a multi-objective optimization approach as given in Table 1 . We consider that the approach of this study is likely to improve the awareness of consumers on their energy usage behaviours. Moreover, consumers can observe and get information on how their preferences influence their savings and comfort. Therefore, they can make an explicit cost-comfort analysis of their energy usage and be stimulated to actively participate in residential DR programs. Given the above literature survey and assessments, the main contributions of this study can be addressed as follows: • Considering the lack of consensus on a unified categorization of household appliances from a HEMS perspective, a comprehensive model-based categorization of household appliances is introduced. • Five types of discomfort are modelled to represent and measure all possible discomfort types resulting from the HEMS’s operation, which enables an explicit cost-comfort analysis. • A new multi-objective HEMS structure is proposed to conveniently provide the trade-off between the consumer’s daily electricity bill and discomfort. • Various electricity tariffs such as TOU, DAP, and CPP are considered to discuss the impact of the implemented pricing strategy on HEMS outputs. 1.4 Paper organization The remainder of this paper is organized as follows: An overview of the proposed HEMS structure in terms of DR modelling of household appliances and related discomfort types is introduced in Section 2. The problem formulation and solution methodology are presented in Section 3. Simulations are performed, and results are evaluated in Section 4. Finally, the conclusion is addressed in Section 5. 2 Overview of the proposed HEMS structure The proposed HEMS structure has an operation length of 24 h, from 06:00 to 06:00 (of the next day). To manage the energy consumption of the household at shorter time slots, a 15-min time resolution is employed, and accordingly, the whole time horizon is given by T ≜ 1 , 2 , 3 , … , t , … , T , where T = 96 i . e . , 05 : 45 . A household appliance has the index i, and the set of all household appliances is represented by I . The variable x i t is used to denote the power consumption of appliance i at time slot t, and has the unit of kW. Each appliance has an operation time window T i preferred by the consumer, indicating that an appliance i is allowed to be managed by the HEMS only within T i given by (1) T i = α i , α i + 1 , … , β i - 1 , β i ⊆ T , ∀ i ∈ I where α i and β i are the preferred earliest starting and latest finishing time of appliance i, respectively. Besides, each appliance has an actual starting and finishing time of operation, t i s and t i f , respectively, such that (2) α i ⩽ t i s < t i f ⩽ β i , ∀ i ∈ I Also, each appliance has a minimum and maximum power consumption limit during its operation, x i min and x i max , respectively. This limitation is given by (3) x i min ⩽ x i t ⩽ x i max , ∀ t ∈ T i , ∀ i ∈ I Outside the operation time window, there is no power consumption by an appliance. That is (4) x i t = 0 , ∀ t ∈ T ⧹ T i , ∀ i ∈ I 2.1 Categorization of household appliances From a HEMS perspective, household appliances can be divided into two main categories according to their flexibility, such as inflexible and flexible appliances. The flexible appliances can then be separated into two categories depending on the feature that brings flexibility to their operation, namely power flexible and time flexible appliances. These main categories and their sub-categories are presented as follows. 2.1.1 Inflexible appliances Inflexible appliances are represented by the set I iflx . The operation of these appliances highly depends on consumer preferences and lifestyles. Therefore, they must operate with the desired power x i des at any time the consumer requests. In other words, the HEMS is unpermitted to adjust the power or schedule the operation time of inflexible appliances. TV, computer, iron, oven, etc. can be included in this category. The power usage of an inflexible appliance i can be given by (5) x i t = x i des , t = t i s , t i s + 1 , … , t i f - 1 , t i f , ∀ i ∈ I iflx 2.1.2 Flexible appliances Flexible appliances are represented by the set I flx . The flexibility of an appliance in the proposed HEMS structure is associated with its controllability in the amount or timing of power usage. Hence, the HEMS is allowed to manage these appliances in power or time. Flexible appliances can be analysed under two categories, namely power flexible and time flexible appliances. • Power flexible appliances: This category is represented by the set I pf flx . The power consumption of each appliance in this category can be adjusted considering (3). However, a power flexible appliance is strict in operation time, which implies that neither delay nor interruption are allowed. Hence, we have t i s = α i , t i s + 1 = α i + 1 , … , t i f - 1 = β i - 1 , and t i f = β i , ∀ i ∈ I pf flx . The utility is a measure of how a consumer’s preference impacts his/her satisfaction from receiving a service. Therefore, this study employs a utility function given in (6) to represent consumer comfort while using a power flexible appliance. (6) U i λ i = λ i 1 - p i 1 - p i , ∀ i ∈ I pf flx where 0 < p i < 1 is the preference parameter of the consumer on power flexible appliances. λ i is the variable of a power flexible appliance i, and adjusted by the HEMS. Note that the same utility can be obtained for higher values of λ i as p i increases, which refers to a decrease in consumer’s willingness to make compromise on his/her routine of using appliance i [61]. λ i can be used to characterize the operation of a power flexible appliance, and this underlies the way of dividing power flexible appliances into three sub-categories as follows: (i) Instant power-based appliances: This sub-category is represented by the set I pf , 1 flx . The comfort provided for the consumer while using an appliance in this sub-category is a function of the instant power of the appliance, and can be measured by (7) U i x i t , t = x i t 1 - p i 1 - p i , ∀ t ∈ T i , ∀ i ∈ I pf , 1 flx A room humidifier with adjustable humidistat setting, electric fans with adjustable fan speeds, or dimmable lights (DLs), as the major shareholder of a household’s illumination load, can be integrated into this sub-category. Thereby, this study assumes that there exist n i DLs in the household. The power consumption of n i DLs is managed by the HEMS in a bulk manner within the operational power limits given by (8), which is the modified version of (3). (8) n i x i min ⩽ x i t ⩽ n i x i max , ∀ t ∈ T i , ∀ i ∈ I pf , 1 flx DLs are responsible for providing a certain luminosity. Thus, the following operational constraint is defined to ensure that the total illumination load power is greater than a preset requisite value. (9) ∑ t ∈ T i x i t ⩾ n i x i max Q i · | T i | , ∀ i ∈ I pf , 1 flx where Q i ⩾ 1 is a coefficient that expresses the consumer’s preference on the required luminosity level. Note that Q i may get different values depending on the time of the day (e.g., day-time or night-time). For example, Q i gets lower values during the night-time periods than the day-time periods since the consumer is likely to need much luminosity during this period. (ii) Energy-based appliances: This sub-category is represented by the set I pf , 2 flx . Appliances in this sub-category can be conceived as battery-assisted appliances that have adjustable charging power. Therefore, the consumer’s comfort when using an appliance in this sub-category is a function of the final energy level E i f , and can be measured by (10) U i E i f = E i f 1 - p i 1 - p i , ∀ i ∈ I pf , 2 flx (11) E i f = E i ini + ∑ t ∈ T i x i t · Δ h N , ∀ i ∈ I pf , 2 flx where E i ini is the initial energy level of appliance i. N is a division factor used to divide the one-hour interval (i.e., Δ h = 1 h) into 15-min slots, and thus N is set to 4. To avoid much loss of comfort, the final energy level needs to be greater than a preset requisite value. Thus, the following constraint is defined, that implies the total energy consumed by an energy-based appliance at the end of the charging process must guarantee that the final energy level reaches at least half of the maximum capacity denoted by E i max before the consumer starts using it. (12) ∑ t ∈ T i x i t · Δ h N ⩾ E i max 2 - E i ini , ∀ i ∈ I pf , 2 flx Electric or Plug-in hybrid electric vehicles can be assigned to this sub-category. This study assumes that the consumer has one electric vehicle (EV) with adjustable charging power. EVs can also be utilized as a supply source to cover a portion of the household load demand. However, due to comfort-driven concerns of the proposed HEMS structure, this study discusses only the charging mode of EV as an energy-consuming appliance similar to the other appliances in the household. (iii) Temperature-based appliances: This sub-category is represented by the set I pf , 3 flx . The appliances in this sub-category are used to adjust the temperature of the environment in which they operate. Hence, the comfort provided for the consumer by an appliance in this sub-category is a function of the adjusted temperature rather than directly being the power consumption or energy level. It can be measured by (13) U i T i , in t = T i , in t 1 - p i 1 - p i , ∀ t ∈ T i , ∀ i ∈ I pf , 3 flx where T i , in t is the inside temperature at time slot t. Note that in addition to (3), there exists an operational temperature limit for an appliance in this sub-category, such that (14) T i , in min ⩽ T i , in t ⩽ T i , in max , ∀ t ∈ T i , ∀ i ∈ I pf , 3 flx where T i , in min and T i , in max are the minimum and maximum inside temperature values desired by the consumer, respectively. The evolution of inside temperature can be expressed by the following linear dynamics [62,63]: (15) T i , in t = T i , in t - 1 + Ω 1 , i T out t - T i , in t - 1 - Ω 2 , i x i t , ∀ t ∈ T i , ∀ i ∈ I pf , 3 flx where T out t is the outside temperature at time slot t. Ω 1 , i and Ω 2 , i are the parameters that refer to the thermal and operational properties of the household and appliance, respectively. These parameters can be defined by (16) Ω 1 , i = 1 - e - Δ t / τ i and (17) Ω 2 , i = η i R i Ω 1 , i , if appliance runs on cooling - η i R i Ω 1 , i , if appliance runs on heating where τ i is the time constant of the system that determines the thermal loss, while R i is thermal resistance in the unit of ° C/kW. η i is thermal conversion efficiency for heating mode and coefficient of performance for cooling mode [64]. Electric space/water heaters or coolers, air conditioners ACs , or in general, heating, ventilation, and air conditioning HVAC loads can be included in this sub-category. In this study, it is assumed that the consumer has an AC which runs on cooling mode for space conditioning as an HVAC load. • Time flexible appliances: This category is represented by the set I tf flx . The operation time of each appliance in this category can be scheduled considering (2). However, a time flexible appliance is not adjustable in power consumption, thus runs on a fixed power during its operation, which can be expressed by the following: (18) x i t = u i t x i max + 1 - u i t x i min , ∀ t ∈ T i , ∀ i ∈ I tf flx (19) u i t = 0 , 1 , if t ∈ T i 0 , if t ∈ T ⧹ T i where u i t is a binary variable used to indicate the ON i . e . , u i t = 1 and OFF i . e . , u i t = 0 state of a time flexible appliance i at time slot t. The appliances in this category need to be ON state at least ξ i time slots to complete their tasks. This requirement can be met through ON–OFF switching sequences or consecutive sequences. Thus, this category is divided into two sub-categories according to the way of meeting the task requirement. (i) Preemptive appliances: This sub-category is represented by the set I tf , 1 flx . The operation of a preemptive appliance can be switched ON or OFF until the number of running time slots reaches ξ i . This operational constraint can be expressed by the following: (20) ∑ t = α i β i u i t = ξ i , ∀ i ∈ I tf , 1 flx Appliances in this sub-category have batteries similar to the appliances in the sub-category I pf , 2 flx . However, they can be charged with fixed power levels. For example, kitchen appliances like electric mills, hand-held mixers, or personal grooming appliances like electric shavers and trimmers, or cleaning appliances such as vacuum cleaners can be addressed in this sub-category. Since a robotic vacuum cleaner (RVC), a popular household appliance, has a larger contribution to the household load demand than the other appliances, it may be a more practical candidate to be managed by the HEMS. Hence, we assume that the consumer has one RVC with fixed charging power. (ii) Non-preemptive appliances: This sub-category is represented by the set I tf , 2 flx . Unlike the preemptive appliances, once a non-preemptive appliance is turned ON, it should run at consecutive time slots until the number of running time slots reaches ξ i . This operational constraint can be expressed by the following: (21) ∑ γ = t + 1 t + ξ i u i γ ⩾ ξ i u i t + 1 - u i t , ∀ t ∈ T i , ∀ i ∈ I tf , 2 flx , Washing appliances such as dishwashers DWs or clothes washers CWs can be addressed in this sub-category, and this study assumes that the consumer has one DW and CW. 2.2 Daily electricity bill The proposed HEMS structure operates in response to the daily price signal offered by the DSO to the consumer such that P ≜ ρ 1 , ρ 2 , … , ρ t , … , ρ T , where ρ t is the electricity unit price at time slot t, and has the unit of cents/kWh. The monetary cost of using an appliance i is denoted by F 1 , i , and can be measured by (22) F 1 , i = ∑ t ∈ T i ρ t x i t · Δ h N , ∀ i ∈ I The daily electricity bill of the consumer is denoted by F 1 , and calculated by the following summation: (23) F 1 = ∑ i ∈ I F 1 , i 2.3 Appliance category-based discomfort types In line with the appliance categorization process presented above, this section introduces the proposed models for discomfort types in each appliance sub-category. The discomfort is the outcome of the managed operation of a flexible appliance i by the HEMS, and is denoted by F 2 , i . In the proposed HEMS structure, the numerical values of F 2 , i correspond to a physical meaning denoted by F i phy . The value of F i phy expresses the discomfort induced in the consumer’s daily life. For instance, how many hours the consumer should wait for his/her CW to start washing the clothes or to which capacity his/her EV reaches in the run-up to driving. The details of the discomfort modelling are presented below. 2.3.1 Power deviation This type of discomfort is valid for an appliance i ∈ I pf , 1 flx . The brightness, and thus the power of DLs, can be reduced at the higher-priced slots to reduce the electricity bill of the consumer. Such a reduction can be made at any time slot depending on the price variations without changing the length of pre-determined operation time window. This, in turn, is reflected as a lower level of luminosity induced by power deviation discomfort. Considering (7) and (8), the minimum and maximum utility of the consumer from using DLs are given by (24) U i min = n i x i min 1 - p i 1 - p i , ∀ i ∈ I pf , 1 flx (25) U i max = n i x i max 1 - p i 1 - p i , ∀ i ∈ I pf , 1 flx The instant discomfort is denoted by F 2 , i t , and given by (26) F 2 , i t = ψ t U i x i t , t - U i max 2 , ∀ t ∈ T i , ∀ i ∈ I pf , 1 flx Eq. (26) states that the consumer gets less utility, and thus feels more discomfort as the power of DLs is reduced to lower values from the maximum value. Note that the HEMS tends to by far decrease and increase the power consumption of DLs at relatively higher and lower-priced slots, respectively. To overcome this issue, ψ t is utilized as a function to suppress the power deviation depending on the current electricity unit price such that (27) ψ t = ψ base + ζ | ρ t - ρ avg | , ∀ t ∈ T where 0 ⩽ ψ base ≤ 1 is the base value, and 0 ⩽ ζ ≤ 1 is the price gap coefficient in the unit of kWh/cents. ρ avg is the average electricity unit price during the day. According to Eq. (27), the power deviation is limited for the extreme values of prices since more importance is paid to the consumer’s discomfort as the prices go beyond or below the average price. Based on the instant discomfort, the discomfort due to an instant power-based appliance i within its operation time window is measured by the following: (28) F 2 , i = ∑ t ∈ T i F 2 , i t , ∀ i ∈ I pf , 1 flx The physical meaning of discomfort resulting from the power adjustment of DLs can be considered as the percentage reduction in the maximum illumination load power of the consumer (i.e., the load at the maximum comfort), and defined as follows: (29) F i phy = ∑ t ∈ T i n i x i max - x i t ∑ t ∈ T i n i x i max % , ∀ i ∈ I pf , 1 flx 2.3.2 Energy insufficiency This type of discomfort is valid for an appliance i ∈ I pf , 2 flx . The final energy level of EV can be adjusted to lower values so that the consumer can get more savings, which results in the discomfort of insufficient energy. The minimum and maximum utility of the consumer from using EV are given by (30) U i min = ∑ t ∈ T i x i min · Δ h N + E i ini 1 - p i 1 - p i , ∀ i ∈ I pf , 2 flx (31) U i max = E i max 1 - p i 1 - p i , ∀ i ∈ I pf , 2 flx Considering the above formulations, the discomfort can be expressed by (32) F 2 , i = U i E i f - U i max 2 , ∀ i ∈ I pf , 2 flx Eq. (32) states that the consumer has more discomfort as the difference between the final energy level of EV and the maximum capacity of EV increases. Thus, the physical meaning of discomfort can be considered as the percentage energy reduction relative to the maximum capacity as follows: (33) F i phy = E i max - E i f E i max % , ∀ i ∈ I pf , 2 flx 2.3.3 Temperature deviation This type of discomfort is valid for an appliance i ∈ I pf , 3 flx . During the management of AC, the inside temperature can be set to below or beyond the desired temperature to reduce the cost. The desired temperature of the consumer is denoted by T i des t as follows: (34) T i des t = T i , in min + T i , in max 2 , ∀ t ∈ T i , ∀ i ∈ I pf , 3 flx Thus, the minimum and maximum utility of the consumer from using AC are (35) U i min = T i , in min 1 - p i 1 - p i , ∀ i ∈ I pf , 3 flx (36) U i max = T i des t 1 - p i 1 - p i , ∀ t ∈ T i , ∀ i ∈ I pf , 3 flx The instant discomfort is denoted by F 2 , i t , and given by (37) F 2 , i t = ψ t U i T i , in t - U i max 2 , ∀ t ∈ T i , ∀ i ∈ I pf , 3 flx where ψ t is used to suppress the temperature deviation at the extreme prices as defined in (27). Eq. (37) states that the consumer discomfort increases as the inside temperature deviates from the desired temperature. Based on the instant discomfort, the discomfort due to a temperature-based appliance i within its operation time window is measured by the following: (38) F 2 , i = ∑ t ∈ T i F 2 , i t , ∀ i ∈ I pf , 3 flx The physical meaning of discomfort can be considered as the average of absolute temperature deviation defined by (39) F i phy = 1 | T i | ∑ t ∈ T i | T i , in t - T i des t | , ∀ i ∈ I pf , 3 flx 2.3.4 Interruption This type of discomfort is valid for an appliance i ∈ I tf , 1 flx . The charging process of RVC can be stopped at the higher-priced slots and restarted when the price gets lower. As the frequency of this switching process increases, the consumer may feel more discomfort. Thus, a discomfort formulation is proposed as follows: (40) F 2 , i = δ i t i f - t i s + ξ i - 1 k i , ∀ i ∈ I tf , 1 flx , ∀ t i s ∈ α i , β i - ξ i + 1 , ∀ t i f ∈ t i s + ξ i - 1 , β i where δ i > 0 is the preference parameter of the consumer on the charging of RVC, and k i ⩾ 1 is a preset coefficient. The above formulation allows the starting time slot of RVC charging (i.e., t i s ) to be different from α i , resulting in multiple types of discomfort (i.e., both interruption and delay). To avoid this issue, t i s is set to α i , and accordingly, the discomfort can be reformulated as follows: (41) F 2 , i = δ i t i f - α i + ξ i - 1 k i , ∀ t i f ∈ α i + ξ i - 1 , β i , ∀ i ∈ I tf , 1 flx where α i + ξ i - 1 is the earliest finishing time slot of the appliance. Eq. (41) states that as the finishing time slot of appliance gets closer to the latest finishing time slot β i , the number of interruptions increase, thus the consumer feels more discomfort. The physical meaning of discomfort can be considered as the difference between the actual and earliest possible finishing time of RVC charging in the unit of hour as follows: (42) F i phy = N t i f - α i - ξ i + 1 , ∀ i ∈ I tf , 1 flx 2.3.5 Delay This type of discomfort is valid for an appliance i ∈ I tf , 2 flx . The operation of DW and CW can be shifted to lower-priced time slots to reduce the electricity bill of the consumer. As the consumer waits longer for an appliance to start, he/she may feel further delay discomfort, which can be formulated as follows: (43) Ψ i = t i s - α i β i - α i - ξ i + 1 , ∀ i ∈ I tf , 2 flx (44) F 2 , i = δ i Ψ i , ∀ i ∈ I tf , 2 flx , ∀ t i s ∈ α i , β i - ξ i + 1 where Ψ i is the delay ratio, and δ i > 1 is the preference parameter of the consumer on DW and CW. β i - ξ i + 1 is the latest time slot at which the appliance can start operating. Eq. (43) gets 0 if the appliance starts operating at the first time slot of T i , which is the utmost desired slot for the beginning of operation. Therefore, the discomfort value is set to its lowest value (i.e., 1). If the appliance starts operating at the latest time slot allowed within T i , Eq. (43) gets 1, and in turn the discomfort becomes maximum (i.e., δ i ). The physical meaning of discomfort can be considered as the difference between the actual and utmost desired starting time of DW and CW in the unit of hour as follows: (45) F i phy = N t i s - α i , ∀ i ∈ I tf , 2 flx 3 Problem formulation and methodology The proposed HEMS structure has two objectives. The first one is to minimize the consumer’s daily electricity bill denoted by F 1 , which can be calculated as in Eq. (23). The second one is to minimize the consumer’s daily discomfort denoted by F 2 . Considering the HEMS’s operation based on the modelling procedure presented in the previous section, these objectives are conflicting, which means that an improvement in one objective causes a deterioration in the other objective. Therefore, the optimal solution to the HEMS’s operation can be obtained through a multi-objective optimization approach. To exhibit how the optimal solution is obtained based on the consumer’s priority, a weighted sum method is adopted so that the settings of weights at various values yield a Pareto-front, which is a set of trade-off solutions. The general optimization problem in this study is formulated as follows: (46) min w 1 F 1 + w 2 F 2 subject to operational constraints of household appliances w 1 + w 2 = 1 , w 1 ⩾ 0 and w 2 ⩾ 0 variables power and operation time of household appliances where w 1 and w 2 are the weighting factors on each objective. However, the problem in (46) has a drawback such that the value of each objective has different units, which may affect the optimal solution. Furthermore, the second objective F 2 has an appliance-dependent unit, implying that its value may change for each appliance. For example, it has the unit of hour for an appliance i ∈ I tf , 1 flx , and the unit of kWh 2 for an appliance i ∈ I pf , 2 flx . In order to dissolve the issue originating from the different units of objective functions in the weighted sum method, function normalization methods can be incorporated to obtain non-dimensional objective functions [65]. To this end, this study evaluates the normalization of both objective functions based on appliance sub-categories as follows: (47) F ‾ 1 , i = F 1 , i - F 1 , i min F 1 , i max - F 1 , i min , ∀ i ∈ I pf , 1 flx ∪ I pf , 2 flx ∪ I pf , 3 flx (48) F ‾ 1 , i = F 1 , i F 1 , i max , ∀ i ∈ I tf , 1 flx ∪ I tf , 2 flx where F ‾ 1 , i denotes the normalized cost of using appliance i, while F 1 , i min and F 1 , i max are the minimum and maximum of F 1 , i , respectively such that (49) F 1 , i min = F 1 , i | x i t = x i min , ∀ t ∈ T i , ∀ i ∈ I pf , 1 flx ∪ I pf , 2 flx (50) F 1 , i max = F 1 , i | x i t = x i max , ∀ t ∈ T i , ∀ i ∈ I pf , 1 flx ∪ I pf , 2 flx (51) F 1 , i max = ∑ j = 1 ξ i ρ i j x i max · Δ h N , ∀ i ∈ I tf , 1 flx ∪ I tf , 2 flx where ρ i j is the j th element of the vector P i which is the sorted price in descending order within α i , β i . (52) F ‾ 2 , i = F 2 , i - F 2 , i min F 2 , i max - F 2 , i min , ∀ i ∈ I pf , 1 flx ∪ I pf , 2 flx ∪ I pf , 3 flx (53) F ‾ 2 , i = F 2 , i F 2 , i max , ∀ i ∈ I tf , 1 flx ∪ I tf , 2 flx where F ‾ 2 , i denotes the normalized discomfort due ot appliance i, while F 2 , i min and F 2 , i max are the minimum and maximum of F 2 , i , respectively such that (54) F 2 , i min = ∑ F 2 , i t | x i t = x i max , ∀ t ∈ T i , ∀ i ∈ I pf , 1 flx (55) F 2 , i max = ∑ F 2 , i t | x i t = x i min , ∀ t ∈ T i , ∀ i ∈ I pf , 1 flx (56) F 2 , i min = F 2 , i | U i E i f = U i max , ∀ i ∈ I pf , 2 flx (57) F 2 , i max = F 2 , i | U i E i f = U i min , ∀ i ∈ I pf , 2 flx (58) F 2 , i max = F 2 , i | t i f = β i , ∀ i ∈ I tf , 1 flx (59) F 2 , i max = F 2 , i | t i s = β i - ξ i + 1 , ∀ i ∈ I tf , 2 flx The above procedure transforms F 1 , i and F 2 , i into their non-dimensional counterparts F ‾ 1 , i and F ‾ 2 , i for all appliance sub-categories except for the sub-category I pf , 3 flx . The challenge that lies behind the optimal energy management of an appliance i ∈ I pf , 3 flx is the fact that the current inside temperature is determined by the previous inside temperature and current power consumption of appliance as given in (15). This yields a temporally time coupling constraint. Considering the multi-objective optimization approach of this study, the optimization problem for an appliance i ∈ I pf , 3 flx under operational power, temperature, and time coupling constraints in (3), (14), and (15), respectively, can be established as follows: (60) min w 1 ∑ t ∈ T i ρ t x i t · Δ h N + w 2 ∑ t ∈ T i ψ i t U i T i , in t - U i max 2 subject to 3 , 14 , 15 w 1 + w 2 = 1 , w 1 ⩾ 0 and w 2 ⩾ 0 variables x i t and T i , in t The optimization problem in (60) can be solved at each time slot by expanding the decoupling strategy given in [66] to a multi-objective case. To that end, (15) can be rewritten as (61) x i t = - 1 Ω 2 , i T i , in t - 1 - Ω 1 , i T i , in t - 1 - Ω 1 , i T out t , ∀ t ∈ T i , ∀ i ∈ I pf , 3 flx Substituting (61) into the objective function of (60) yields (62) w 1 ∑ t ∈ T i - ρ t Δ h Ω 2 , i N T i , in t - 1 - Ω 1 , i T i , in t - 1 - Ω 1 , i T out t + w 2 ∑ t ∈ T i ψ t U i T i , in t - U i max 2 , ∀ i ∈ I pf , 3 flx The equivalent form of (62) can be expressed by the following: (63) w 1 Δ h Ω 2 , i N ∑ t = α i β i - 1 - ρ t + 1 - Ω 1 , i ρ t + 1 T i , in t - ρ β i T i , in β i + Φ t + w 2 ∑ t = α i β i ψ t U i T i , in t - U i max 2 , ∀ i ∈ I pf , 3 flx where (64) Φ t = ρ 1 1 - Ω 1 , i T i , in 0 + Ω 1 , i ∑ t = α i β i ρ t T out t , ∀ i ∈ I pf , 3 flx In (63), the optimization variable is only the inside temperature T i , in t , and thus there remains no temporally time coupling constraint. In Eq. (64), T i , in 0 is the initial inside temperature before the appliance starts running, and set to T i , in max . Φ t can be excluded from (63) since it does not include an optimization variable. Eventually, F 1 , i given by Eq. (22) can be rewritten for an appliance i ∈ I pf , 3 flx as follows: (65) F 1 , i = Δ h Ω 2 , i N - ρ t + 1 - Ω 1 , i ρ t + 1 T i , in t , if t ∈ T i ⧹ β i - Δ h Ω 2 , i N ρ t T i , in t , if t = β i Considering (37), (38), and (65), the minimum and maximum of F 1 , i and F 2 , i can obtained by (66) F 2 , i min = ∑ F 2 , i t | T i , in t = T i des t , ∀ t ∈ T i , ∀ i ∈ I pf , 3 flx (67) F 2 , i max = ∑ F 2 , i t | T i , in t = T i , in min , T i , in max , ∀ t ∈ T i , ∀ i ∈ I pf , 3 flx (68) F 1 , i min = A 1 t T i , in max , if t ∈ T i ⧹ β i and A 1 t < 0 A 1 t T i , in min , if t ∈ T i ⧹ β i and A 1 t ⩾ 0 A 2 t T i , in max , if t = β i (69) F 1 , i max = A 1 t T i , in min , if t ∈ T i ⧹ β i and A 1 t < 0 A 1 t T i , in max , if t ∈ T i ⧹ β i and A 1 t ⩾ 0 A 2 t T i , in min , if t = β i where A 1 t = Δ h Ω 2 , i N ( - ρ t + 1 - Ω 1 , i ρ t + 1 ) and A 2 t = - Δ h Ω 2 , i N ( ρ t ) . Note that F 2 , i gets its maximum value for either T i , in t = T i , in max or T i , in t = T i , in min , since T i des t is the average of T i , in max and T i , in min . Given the normalized objective functions of each appliance sub-category which have been obtained so far, the general optimization problem in (46) can be reformulated as follows: (70) min w 1 F ‾ 1 , i + w 2 F ‾ 2 , i subject to 8 , 9 , ∀ t ∈ T i , ∀ i ∈ I pf , 1 flx 3 , 12 , ∀ t ∈ T i , ∀ i ∈ I pf , 2 flx 14 , x i t ⩾ 0 , ∀ t ∈ T i , ∀ i ∈ I pf , 3 flx 18 , 19 , 20 , ∀ t i f ∈ α i + ξ i - 1 , β i , ∀ i ∈ I tf , 1 flx 18 , 19 , 21 , ∀ t i s ∈ α i , β i - ξ i + 1 , ∀ i ∈ I tf , 2 flx w 1 + w 2 = 1 , w 1 ⩾ 0 and w 2 ⩾ 0 variables x i t , ∀ i ∈ I pf , 1 flx ∪ I pf , 2 flx T i , in t , ∀ i ∈ I pf , 3 flx t i f , ∀ i ∈ I tf , 1 flx t i s , u i t , ∀ i ∈ I tf , 2 flx In (70), the conflicting objective functions are non-dimensional for each appliance sub-category. Therefore, the optimal energy usage pattern of the entire household can be obtained without considering the unit of various discomfort types. Smart meter (SM) and appliance control (ACU) unit are the fundamental components of the proposed HEMS structure. SM is deployed at the household for two purposes: (i) to measure and record the power consumption of each appliance, and (ii) to provide bi-directional information flow between the household and DSO. A wireless local area network facility is exploited to provide the two way communication between the household and DSO. ACU is a computer based platform that receives information from SM and household appliances, and accordingly, optimizes the power consumption of each appliance. SM, ACU, and household appliances are in communication by a home area network infrastructure. Practically, the ACU can independently manage the optimization process for each appliance through the distributed algorithm shown in Fig. 1 . The distributed algorithm comprises three layers. At the input layer, the algorithm utilizes two types of inputs, namely consumer and utility inputs. Consumer inputs can be defined as power limits of appliances, requested operation time for appliances, desired indoor temperature, and weighting factor. The electricity pricing tariff and outside temperature are informed by the DSO as the utility inputs. All these data are transmitted through SM as the inputs to the HEMS layer, where ACU initiates and administers the optimization process. To represent the uncertain behaviours of consumers in their appliance usage, of electricity pricing tariffs, and of outside temperature conditions, a scenario generation stage is initially adopted. Then, the appliances that the consumer decides to use are categorized as explained in Section 2. Depending on the appliance, optimization methodology is applied such that the optimal power consumption of AC is obtained at each time slot via β i - α i + 1 number of sub-problems, while the optimal solution to the operation of power and time flexible appliances are obtained by convex and discrete optimization, respectively within an acceptable time. In order to help the consumer to have a better understanding on the HEMS’s operation, the outcomes of the management process (i.e., optimal energy usage pattern of all appliances) are visible to the consumer by a monitoring interface at the output layer. 4 Results and discussion The validation of the proposed HEMS structure is presented in this section. The optimization toolbox of MATLAB R2018a software is used to perform the simulations on a PC with a 3.5 GHz CPU, i7 Core, and 16 GB RAM. To exhibit the stochasticity of appliance usage patterns, electricity unit prices, and outside temperature, a scenario generation based approach via Monte Carlo Simulation (MCS) is adopted in this study. To that end, one hundred scenarios are generated for a 24-h operation of the proposed HEMS structure. On the other hand, three different pricing tariffs are considered to analyse the impact of time-varying electricity unit prices on HEMS outputs. The first pricing tariff is DAP, where prices alter at regular intervals of 15 min. The second pricing tariff is a three-level TOU tariff with peak, mid-peak, and off-peak periods. The third pricing tariff is CPP, where prices are extremely high for a short period of the day, and discounted during the rest of the periods. The electricity unit prices for DAP tariff are extracted from Australian Energy Market Operator in [67], as well. The hourly changing outside temperature given in [29] is discretized into time slots of 15 min, and utilized in the simulations. The generated pricing tariffs and outside temperature for a day based on MCS are depicted in Fig. 2 . Table 2 gives the utility function, discomfort formula, and adjustable parameter for each appliance sub-category. The power consumption data of inflexible appliances are obtained from [11,68], and given in Table 3 . The starting t i s and usage times of inflexible appliances are randomly generated such that ℧ [ x , y ] returns an integer between x and y. Also, note that ℧ r [ x , y ] is used to randomly produce a real number between x and y. Tables 4 and 5 give the parameter setting for each power and time flexible appliance, respectively. This study assumes that DLs have two usage periods in a day such that DLs1 and DLs2 correspond to the usage at the day-time and night-time period, respectively. In order to evaluate how the consumer’s preferences and priorities in the proposed HEMS structure affect his/her bill and comfort, four different cases are described as follows: • Base Case: This case is conducted to provide a benchmark for the other cases. In this case, the proposed HEMS structure is not implemented. The control of dim, EV charging and temperature are not applicable. Therefore, a DL consumes maximum power when it is turned ON and the EV starts being charged with its maximum power just upon arrival at home. The inside temperature is maintained fixed at the desired temperature by the AC during the day. Besides, the consumer charges his/her RVC with no interruption and uses his/her DW and CW with no delay. • Case 1: This case is called the minimum discomfort case (i.e., the maximum cost case), where w 1 and w 2 are set to 0.0 and 1.0, respectively. Hence, it can be concluded that the consumer only cares about his/her comfort similar to the base case. However, the proposed HEMS structure is implemented in this case such that maximum comfort is achieved in the consumer’s daily life. • Case 2: This case is called the moderate case, where w 1 and w 2 are both set to 0.5. The consumer expresses equal concern about his/her bill and discomfort by choosing the same weighting factors. • Case 3: This case is called the minimum cost case (i.e, the maximum discomfort case), where w 1 and w 2 are set to 1.0 and 0.0, respectively. In this case, the consumer only cares about the daily electricity bill and agrees to lose his/her comfort to a certain extent. This study presents the obtained simulation results in two parts. The simulation results of a sample scenario out of the generated scenarios are given in the first part to provide a basis on how the appliances are managed in power and time by the proposed HEMS structure. In the second part, the average result of all scenarios is demonstrated by comparing the implemented pricing tariffs in terms of their effects on HEMS outputs. The pricing tariffs, outside temperature, and power consumption of inflexible appliances in the sample scenario are shown in Fig. 3 , while the parameters used in the simulation are given by Table A.1 in Appendix A. Due to the price variations at short time slots under the DAP tariff, the results obtained for this pricing tariff are given through Figs. 4–7 . Fig. 4(a) shows the power consumption of DLs. In the base case, the monetary cost of using DLs is 53.0 cents, while it is 52.98, 26.51, and 14.83 cents under case 1, case 2, and case 3, respectively. The illumination load power at the day-time and night-time period are 2.0 and 26.1 kW, respectively under the base case, while it is almost the same in case 1. However, if the consumer gives the utmost priority to his/her comfort (i.e., case 3), the illumination load power is reduced to 0.63 and 10.9 kW for the day-time and night-time period, respectively. Note that the ratio of illumination load power under the base case to that under case 3 equals 3.178 and 2.398 (i.e., Q i values in Table A.1) for the day-time and night-time period, respectively. The consumer may desire further total luminosity level by setting a lower value of Q i considering the constraint in (9). If the consumer chooses to be moderate (i.e., case 2), the total illumination load power rises to 14.78 kW from 11.53 kW, and thus a higher luminosity level is obtained as compared to case 3. As can be seen from Fig. 4(a), the power consumption of DLs is responsive to the price variations such that the DLs are dimmed at the higher-priced slots, and then brightened again at the lower-priced slots to accomplish the desired illumination load power. Compared to case 3, the luminosity level at each time slot is closer to the average luminosity in case 2, implying that the consumer does not feel drastic brightness changes. Fig. 4(b) depicts the charging power of EV. Under the base case, the EV immediately starts being charged at 18:30 with a 3.3 kW power upon arrival at home. The charging process ends at 21:45, indicating that the EV charging coincides with the peak-priced slots between 18:00 and 22:00. In case 1, the charging power of EV is constant at 0.8 kW regardless of the price variations since the consumer’s priority is to have a fully charged vehicle before 08:30. However, in case 2 and case 3, the charging power at each time slot is adjusted according to the price at the relevant time slot. The charging of EV costs the consumer about 117, 67.6, 50.1, and 18.9 cents for the base case, case 1, case 2, and case 3, respectively. As can be concluded from Fig. 4(c), under the base case and case 1, the capacity of EV reaches 16 kWh (i.e., full capacity). In case 2, the capacity of EV is slightly reduced to 15.41 kWh. However, the EV capacity further decreases to its half capacity in case 2 as required in (12), resulting in 50% comfort loss in return for 72% cost saving in comparison to case 1. Fig. 5 demonstrates how the power consumption of AC and inside temperature are adjusted. In the base case and case 1, the inside temperature is always set to the desired value of 23.36 ° C as given in Fig. 5(a) since the HEMS is not implemented in the base case and the consumer makes no compromise on his/her thermal comfort in case 1. The usage of AC to maintain the inside temperature at the desired level all day long contributes nearly 266 cents to the daily electricity bill of the consumer. As can be inferred from Fig. 5(a) and (c), in case 3, the inside temperature is set to the minimum value of 22.43 ° C according to the difference between the price at the current and next time slot such that if ρ t - 1 - Ω 1 , i ρ t + 1 < 0 , the inside temperature is lowered to the minimum value at time slot t before the price rises at time slot t + 1 . Similarly, the inside temperature is set to the maximum value of 24.29 ° C at time slot t + 1 where the price is higher. Through this temperature adjustment, the inside temperature is decreased and increased at the lower and higher-priced slots, respectively so that the rise in power consumption of AC does coincide with the higher-priced slots as can be seen in Fig. 5(b). The share of AC in consumer’s daily electricity bill in case 3 decreases from 266 cents to 234.4 cents, while the average resultant inside temperature rises to 24.15 ° C from 23.36 ° C. This refers to a temperature deviation of 0.79 ° C from the desired level. However, the price-driven decrement and increment of the inside temperature are limited in case 2 as compared to case 3 since the HEMS aims at achieving a trade-off between the payment and comfort loss. Accordingly, the consumer pays 252.12 cents for using his/her AC in case 2, where the average resultant inside temperature is 23.48 ° C. This causes a relieved temperature deviation of 0.12 ° C. The power consumption of RVC is shown in Fig. 6. In the base case and case 1, the charging of RVC begins at 19:00, the first time slot of its operation time window, and it takes 75 min (i.e., ξ i = 5 ) to complete the charging task. As can be seen from Fig. 6, the charging of RVC is not interrupted in both of these two cases. The resultant cost of consecutive charging is about 7.05 cents. In case 2, one interruption occurs, and thus the consumer waits 30 min for his/her RVC to restart being charged. The consumer pays 5.92 cents for charging RVC in case 2. As for case 3, although the RVC charging starts at 19:00, two interruptions occur at the higher-priced slots. Consequently, the consumer’s total waiting time rises to 5 h from 30 min, whereas the cost decreases from 5.92 cents to 3.48 cents. The power consumption of DW and CW are given by Fig. 7(a) and (b), respectively. It can be seen from Fig. 7(a) that the DW starts its operation at 18:00 with no delay, and runs for 45 min (i.e., ξ i = 3 ) in the base case and case 1. However, the starting time of DW is shifted to 22:45 in case 2 to provide a trade-off between the cost and comfort of the consumer. The number of shifted hours at the starting time of DW further increases such that the consumer needs to wait 5 h and 30 min for his/her DW to start operating until 01:30 in case 3. The cost of using the DW for the consumer is 9.36 cents in the base case and case 1, while it reduces to 4.8 and 4 cents in case 2 and case 3, respectively. As can be seen from Fig. 7(b), in the base case and case 1, the CW starts operating at 17:15, the utmost desired time slot, and runs for 75 min (i.e., ξ i = 5 ) to complete its task. The consumer pays 12.37 cents if delay at the starting time is not allowed. However, in case 2, the starting time of CW becomes 18:00 with a delay of 45 min, and this shifted operation slightly reduces the cost from 12.37 cents to 12.15 cents. In case 3, the starting time of CW is shifted 6 h and 15 min and becomes 23:30. Such a shifting leads to a considerable cost saving of 7.28 cents, and the consumer pays 5.09 cents for using his/her CW at late night hours. The total power consumption of the household under each pricing tariff for the sample scenario is demonstrated in Fig. 8 . In the base case, the household load power increases at early times of the day when people are awake before going out for work. Similarly, when the people return home, the load demand considerably rises since the household appliances are actively used at the evening hours. This causes a high cost resulting from the fact that the growth of demand matches the higher-priced slots. Accordingly, the consumer’s daily electricity bill equals nearly 615.1, 711.5, and 656.6 cents under DAP, TOU, and CPP tariff, respectively in the base case. However, in case 1 where the proposed HEMS structure serves so that the consumer gets the highest comfort, the consumer’s daily bill reduces to 566.5, 642.4, and 569.7 cents for DAP, TOU, and CPP tariff, respectively. These savings reveal the functionality of the proposed HEMS structure even though the consumer’s priority is his/her comfort. Despite no delay, interruption or energy reduction, the automation based energy usage pattern of appliances enable the consumer to acquire financial benefits without no-ill effect in their daily comfort. Unlike case 1, the saving in the consumer’s daily electricity bill in case 2 and case 3 stems from the reduced and shifted consumption of the household appliances. In case 2, the daily bill is reduced to 512.1, 573.7, and 512.3 cents for DAP, TOU, and CPP tariff, respectively, while the consumer’s daily discomfort calculated by F ‾ 2 = 1 I flx ∑ i ∈ I flx F ‾ 2 , i equals 0.339, 0.336, and 0.316 for DAP, TOU, and CPP tariff, respectively. If the consumer’s priority is his/her cost (i.e., case 3), the daily bill further decreases to 435.9, 486.8, and 426.3 cents for DAP, TOU, and CPP tariff, respectively. This cost priority increases the discomfort from 0.339 to 0.868 under DAP, from 0.336 to 0.828 under TOU, and from 0.316 to 0.832 under CPP tariff. In a nutshell, the consumer may determine the amount and timing his/her load demand, and in turn his/her bill and incurred discomfort by adjusting the appropriate weighting factors. In the second part of the obtained simulation results, the average of all generated scenarios is presented. The first result is the average power consumption of the household for each pricing tariff and weighting factor, and shown in Fig. 9 . In Fig. 9(a), there seem to be sharp increases and decreases in power consumption within the time interval of 11:00 and 15:00, especially when the consumer pays more importance to his/her cost saving. The main reason that lies behind this excessive change in power consumption is that the price fluctuations in the DAP tariff drive the AC to switch the inside temperature from the minimum to the maximum or vice versa. The high outside temperatures during this interval can be regarded as another factor that contributes to the rise in power consumption. The common point to be mentioned for power consumption pattern under all pricing tariffs is that the peak load is relieved during the peak-priced hours, and the load demand is shifted to the late night hours as the consumer’s willingness to change his/her daily energy routine increases. Therefore, the power grid can be de-stressed from the utility perspective. From the end-user perspective, consumers can be encouraged to adopt HEMSs by enabling them to get the knowledge and awareness on how their preferences are reflected in their budget and comfort in addition to the power grid operation. In the base case given in Fig. 9(a)–(c), the consumer’s daily electricity bill amounts 5.62 $, 6.12 $, and 7.80 $ under DAP, TOU, and CPP tariff respectively. The highest bill arises under the CPP tariff since the electricity unit prices are very high during the peak-priced period in this tariff as compared to the peak prices in the other tariffs. Therefore, the accumulation of load demand at the peak-priced period results in a higher cost. The Pareto-front obtained for each generated scenario and pricing tariff is demonstrated in Fig. 10 . The average of all generated scenarios yields the results given in Table 6 , where F 1 avg and F ‾ 2 avg are calculated by Eq. (B.3) and (B.4) in Appendix B, respectively. The relevant Pareto-fronts are shown in Fig. 11 . The detailed appliance-based results are given by Tables B.1–B.6 in Appendix B, as well. According to Table 6, the average daily bill ranges from 4.062 $ to 5.145 $ in the DAP tariff, from 4.251 $ to 5.447 $ in the TOU tariff, and from 5.302 $ to 6.801 $ in the CPP tariff. The minimum of average discomfort is 0.234 in all pricing tariffs. Note that this discomfort value is due to the calculation of discomfort for DW and CW in Eq. (44). However, as can be seen in Tables B.5 and B.6, the consumer doesn’t have any physical discomfort since no delay at the starting time is allowed in case 1. The maximum of average discomfort equals 0.859, 0.792, and 0.782 in the DAP, TOU, and CPP tariff, respectively. Evaluating the average results in case 1, case 2, and case 3, it can be deduced that the DAP tariff outperforms better results in meeting the consumer’s priorities. In case 1, the lowest bill is achieved under the DAP tariff for a comfort-priority consumer. Therefore, the consumer reaps the benefit of paying less with no impairment in his/her comfort. In case 2, the moderate consumer who desires to reduce this/her cost without a considerable comfort loss has the lowest bill and discomfort in the DAP tariff, indicating that the requirements are met considering his/her priorities. As for case 3, where the consumer only cares about his/her cost, the lowest bill is again achieved under the DAP tariff. Although the consumer already agrees to lose his/her daily comfort to a certain extent, it should be noted that the implementation of the DAP tariff causes the highest discomfort in case 3 as might be expected. This is essentially due to the operation of the HEMS managing the appliances in response to the price variations. The 15-min variations of electricity unit prices in the DAP tariff result in more frequent changes in the operation of appliances, and in turn further price-driven discomfort. Nevertheless, it should be highlighted that a power grid supplies the load demand of a large number of consumers with various electricity usage routines and priorities. Regarding the diversity of consumers in a power grid, it may be more realistic to compare the implemented pricing tariffs by averaging the results of all ( w 1 , w 2 ) pairs. The price-based comparison of the average results is depicted in Fig. 12 . The average daily bill equals 4.67 $, 4.87 $, and 5.86 $ for DAP, TOU, and CPP tariff, respectively, while the average daily discomfort is 0.38, 0.41, and 0.40 DAP, TOU, and CPP tariff, respectively. These results reveal that the DAP tariff is still the most beneficial one among the other tariffs, independently of consumer types with any priority. The superior performance of the DAP tariff results from its efficiency in reflecting the dynamic costs of electricity generation in the power market. Thus, the implementation of DAP tariff may serve to improve social welfare during all day, not just during the peak-priced hours. The change of computational time with the increasing scenario number in the proposed HEMS structure is given in Table 7 . It also takes different times to find the optimal solution depending on the implemented pricing tariff. The average computational time indicates that the proposed HEMS structure finds the optimal power consumption scheme of the entire household within an acceptable time duration. Note that the stochastic scenarios are generated in this study to verify the effectiveness of the proposed HEMS structure in accomplishing the optimality under variable input parameters. Therefore, to get the optimal solution under the pre-determined input parameters (i.e., NS = 1 ) within nearly 16 s can be considered as an acceptable time. 5 Conclusions This paper has proposed a new multi-objective HEMS structure considering a comprehensive model-based categorization of household appliances and relevant discomfort types. The basic goal underlying the motivation to design the proposed HEMS structure is to provide the consumer with the facility of making an explicit cost-comfort analysis on his/her daily energy usage routines. To this end, appliance category-based discomfort models have been developed at the first stage. Then, function normalization methods have been applied at the second stage to avoid the effect of conflicting objective functions with different units on the optimal solution. To observe how the consumer’s priority determines the optimal HEMS operation, the weighted sum method has been adopted in a multi-objective optimization framework. Moreover, a stochastic scenario generation process based on MCS approach has been carried out to represent the uncertainty in appliance usage patterns, electricity pricing tariffs, and outside temperature. Different case studies under various pricing tariffs have been conducted to verify the effectiveness of the proposed HEMS structure. The results have shown that the optimal energy consumption pattern of the household is conveniently achieved within an acceptable time by taking the consumer’s preferences and requirements into account. Depending on the consumer’s priority, the trade-off between the daily electricity bill and discomfort is provided. On the other hand, the results have indicated that the DAP tariff yields prominent results from the end-user perspective. From the utility perspective, the load curve has been modified such that the peak load of the system is relieved through the shifting and reduction of power consumption of household appliances. Observing and assessing the presented results in this study, it can be considered that consumers can be promoted to participate in residential DR programs through HEMSs by providing them with the knowledge and awareness on how their preferences are reflected in their budget and comfort in addition to the power grid operation. Additionally, consumers can appreciate a meaningful balance between their cost savings and comfortable lifestyles. Finally, it can be concluded that the implementation of short-time interval-varying pricing tariffs may serve to improve social welfare. coredata.dc:description: Residential consumers can get the opportunity to render their energy usage responsive to time-varying prices by participating in demand response (DR) programs through home energy management systems (HEMSs). The consumer’s primary motivation behind utilizing a HEMS is to reduce cost, which entails a shifted or reduced power consumption associated with the impairment in daily comfort. In this regard, a HEMS needs to maintain the consumer’s comfort while minimizing his/her cost. Besides, a residential consumer may desire to use various appliances in a day. The managed operation of these appliances in a HEMS environment results in diverse types of discomfort peculiar to each appliance. Therefore, this study initially develops discomfort models in a comprehensive manner and then proposes a new multi-objective HEMS, aiming to bring cost savings to the consumer without considerable discomfort in his/her daily life under various operating conditions such as different pricing tariffs and stochastic scenarios. The results prove that the proposed HEMS conveniently achieves the optimal energy usage pattern of the household depending on consumer preferences and priorities. Moreover, it is revealed that a residential consumer can make an explicit cost-comfort analysis and appreciate a meaningful balance between his/her cost-saving and comfortable lifestyle.
coredata.dc:title: A multi-objective home energy management system for explicit cost-comfort analysis considering appliance category-based discomfort models and demand response programs
